ai-tha-ap333:1.1_0: “There is no need for the Fortunate One,
ai-tha-ap333:2.2_0: in the world with its gods.
ai-tha-ap333:2.3_0: like Indra, the finest of gods.
ai-tha-ap333:2.4_0: Burning is burning with the sacrifice;
ai-tha-ap333:3.2_0: I was born in my hair dishevelled:
ai-tha-ap333:3.4_0: at the fore of the mendicant Saṅgha,
ai-tha-ap333:4.2_0: Having raised my joined palms to him:
ai-tha-ap333:4.3_0: I paid homage at the teacher’s feet,
ai-tha-ap333:5.1_0: if he makes his four eons;
ai-tha-ap333:5.3_0: I’m not aware of any living creatures.
ai-tha-ap333:6.3_0: I’ve realized the six kinds of direct knowledge,
ai-tha-ap333:7.1_0: That is how these verses were recited by the senior venerable Gandhāra.
